There is a financial literacy epidemic in America. 

Quick lesson: NYC wasn’t handing cash to Amazon. It was an incentive program based on job creation, producing tax revenue. 

There isn’t a $3 billion pile of money that can now be spent on subways or education.

1119693778372190210.text: DAI can't compare stability to USD-pegged currencies, and significantly more volatile than regulated stablecoins. However, it does offer permissionless properties. Is ~30% annual vol considered a win, given "decentralized"? Comparing to ETH as a funding mechanism, I'd say yes

1119693775285170176.text: Tbf the purpose of the entire system is to prop up its stablecoin, DAI. A lot has been said about the inability to maintain a pure $1 peg, but I think daily price volatility is a better benchmark to measure "stability" relative to other dollar-pegged currencies, fiatcoins, etc.pic.twitter.com/FWRWDDiQhu

1119674287777046528.text: Maker's CDP system should never have been marketed as a consumer finance product. It's a margin lending tool. Posting a blog of borrower stories using CDP positions to buy their "dream car" or pay off a mortgage hasn't aged well. https://medium.com/makerdao/dai-cdp-user-stories-36735f095fda …https://twitter.com/timothyjcoulter/status/1119444473832804353 …

1119038917028741122.text: Fin/ Considering growing competition from both non-custodial protocols and centralized lenders, no real moat from Maker itself, and a literal ceiling on loan growth (debt ceiling currently set at 100m) - I'll leave for you to decide if current MKR valuations seem reasonable

1119038915934134272.text: 14/ Given the current market cap, a 30x multiple would imply realized earnings of over $23 million. Remember annualized 1Q19 revenues are running at ~$400K (and trading at +2000x PE)...

1119038914801623040.text: 13/ Now lets say a "justified" multiple for MKR is arbitrarily 30x -  which would be quite rich for a pure-play overcollateralized credit facility - but let's assume those cost efficiencies really move the needle as the platform scales

1119038913149112320.text: 12/ In fact, publicly traded secured lending companies (acknowledging not apples to apples to Maker) actually trade below higher quality credit lending operations, typically anywhere from 8-14x on a trailing basispic.twitter.com/VsDm1B75N2

1119038908036210689.text: 11/ Leaving aside the fact that MKR is not equity and has no direct rights outside of 1 token one vote for protocol changes, the reality is lending companies never warrant a trailing PE multiple above 20x

1119038906777755648.text: 10/ 65x, that's not bad for a high growth company some will say. Amazon trades at +90x... 65x seems reasonable for a #DeFi credit facility...

1119038905519570944.text: 9/ Others have also been quick to point out that if you assume all CDP's (~$90m) are paid off at a current rate of 11.5% the PE would be ~65x and yield would be 1.5%. Ok, sure...

1119038903774863361.text: 8/ Currently with single collateral DAI, none of the liquidation fees go to MKR holders, but if you add that in to total "earnings" the PE falls to 120x, and yield moves up to .80%pic.twitter.com/hlYlrluHMw

1119038898636775425.text: 7/ Sidebar: what's great about playing with this data is you can see potential incremental value drivers. In current form, PETH holders have received 96% of DAI disbursements via the 13% liquidation fee...pic.twitter.com/xBJwJN6SO1

1119038894228557824.text: 6/ Now some will be quick to point out that rates just started getting off zero in 4Q. However even annualizing 1Q realized revenues (~$100k) would still return a +1800x PE and a .05% earnings yield

1119038891498123264.text: 5/ A +3,000x PE doesn't mean much, so you can take the inverse and get an earnings yield (or the return per dollar invested) for a better comparison. This returns this:pic.twitter.com/IUpj9XF0nQ

1119038887303831553.text: 4/ To calculate "earnings" we went with realized interest payments rather than accrued interest on outstanding balances as interest in Maker is variable and only paid when closing a CDPpic.twitter.com/UUrzhCf4tX

1119038881800830978.text: 3/ But seeing how nascent the MakerDAO system is, and the fact that we have zero consensus in the market on what rates will even be in two weeks, projecting a forward 12 month multiple seems unrealistic at this time...

1119038880576151552.text: 2/ As a rule of thumb, the later could be construed as investment advice, which we do not provide

1119038879250681856.text: 1/ Some are wondering why trailing 12-month "PE" rather than forward? This work was a look at measuring actual performance relative to very loose comparables, and not an attempt to forecast or back into some hypothetical target price or valuation

1119038877786955776.text: TL;DR: real-time earnings data for DAOs is an analyst's dream. h/t to @marcandu for sharing the data he pulled from Maker's smart contracts. Some thoughts on the feedback we received:https://twitter.com/hasufl/status/1118858417052049409 …

1102983624901775365.text: Conclusion: Only product market fit I see today with #defi vs centralized lenders is being able to fund borrowers on financial sanctions lists and potential efficiency gains on sec lending/margin trading for retail investors (most institutional investors require KYC)

1102983480353456128.text: 6/If comparing utility for consumer fi, centralized lenders can out-compete more “efficient” protocols by offering strong fiat rails with direct funding to bank accounts, pass through insured custody (BlockFi uses Bitgo), customer support, and targeted regional product offerings

1102983425173143552.text: 5/However, savings accounts in Japan offer practically zero. 6% rate is eye-watering. In a conversation with BlockFi, the team noted the response to the soft launch of savings product in Japan was very strong

1102983365601431553.text: 4/Re: product differentiation with a global mindset. Different markets see different product demand. A retail borrower getting 4-4.5% on secured loan in Latin America is amazing, in Japan with a negative rate environment, that's terrible

1102983310828101634.text: 3/Additionally, don't discount the value customer relationships hold within consumer fi, even within digital lending. Classic example: SoFi welcome kits sent to new borrowers can include t-shirts, bottle openers, olive oil, etc. It's the little things that build customer loyalty

1102983231773790208.text: 2/Re customer experience. Unlike Maker which liquidates positions without compromise (and rub salt in the wound with 13% liquidation fee), companies like BlockFi can offer flexible payment extensions in case of unexpected circumstances. Consumer Fi ex: hurricane relief extensions

1102983183455391744.text: 1/ Lending and deposit taking is a business model with few levers for differentiation, but it’s an industry where customer experience and competitive product offerings absolutely moves the needle towards building a stickier deposit base

1102983075519184896.text: BlockFi offering 6.2% on both BTC and ETH deposits changes the game. Will be interesting to see if/how centralized crypto deposit takers and lenders impact #DeFi volumes overtime. A thread:
